reference: Volume Four, Issue Forty-Two, File 13 of 14
title: HoHoCon 1992 Miscellany
historical_context: HoHoCon was a significant gathering in hacker culture, occurring during a time of heightened scrutiny from authorities towards hacker conventions.
target_audience: Hackers, security professionals, and those interested in hacker culture history.
short_summary: This article recounts the events and atmosphere of HoHoCon 1992, detailing the interactions among attendees, notable speakers, and the overall vibe of the convention amidst fears of police raids.
summary:
The article provides a vivid narrative of the HoHoCon 1992, capturing the essence of the hacker community during a time of uncertainty. Attendees were on edge due to recent police actions at similar events, yet many were determined to attend regardless. The author describes the chaotic yet vibrant atmosphere at the Allen Park Inn, where hackers mingled, shared stories, and engaged in discussions about Unix security and other topics. Notable figures like John Draper (Captain Crunch) made appearances, adding to the eclectic mix of personalities present. The article highlights various speeches, including discussions on cellular fraud, UFO conspiracies, and the legal implications of hacking, showcasing the diverse interests of the hacker community at the time.

As the convention progressed, the author notes the camaraderie and mischief that characterized the event, from humorous interactions with hotel staff to the antics of attendees. The narrative culminates in reflections on the convention's organization and the wealth of information shared, contrasting it with previous years' more anarchistic tendencies. Overall, the piece serves as both a historical account and a celebration of the unique culture that defined HoHoCon 1992.
